bibl.title: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1947

div1.p: Sawyer informs Hench that he is not in a position to approach John D. Rockefeller, Jr. on Hench's behalf, but sees no reason why Hench or the Mayo Clinic should not contact Rockefeller. Sawyer would like to hold a special session on Reed or yellow fever at the upcoming International Congress on Tropical Medicine and Malaria and solicits ideas from Hench.

div1.head: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1947
div1.opener:
4th INTERNATIONAL CONGRESSES
on Tropical Medicine and Malaria
In reply refer to
IC 512.819
ORGANIZING COMMITTEE-DEPARTMENT OF STATE-WASHINGTON 23, D C
DIVISION OF INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES
DEPARTMENT OF STATE
WASHINGTON 25, D.C.
June 26, 1947
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Dr. Strode has forwarded to me a copy of your
letter of May 12, 1947, addressed to me at the
Rockefeller Foundation, New York City. Unfortunately,
I did not receive it until after the beginning of the
meeting of the American Medical Association. Circum-
stances prevented me from attending that meeting and
running across you there.

As Dr. Strode informed you, I retired from the
International Health Division in 1944, and for the
past 3 years have been Director of Health for UNRRA.
Now I am attached to the Division of International
Conferences, Department of State, and am engaged in
organizing the Fourth International Congresses on
Tropical Medicine and Malaria to be held May 10-18,
1948.

I am not in a position to approach Mr. John D.
Rockefeller, Jr., but I see no reason why you, or
the Mayo Clinic, should not do so. If Mr. Rockefeller
should ask for my opinion, I should, of course, be
very glad to give it and I feel very friendly toward
your project.

There have been some developments which bear
on your proposals and which would involve the
Congresses which I am helping to organize. You are
probably aware that Walter Reed was elected to the
Hall of Fame last year but that the funds necessary
to provide for the bust and its installation have
not been secured. I understand that it would cost
about $6,000. It has been suggested that it would
be very timely if the unveiling could occur at the
time of the international meeting on tropical medicine
and be
Dr. P. S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
- 2 -
and be related to a special session on either Walter
Reed or yellow fever in general. It occurs to me
that it might be of advantage if your project could
come to a head at about the same time. Doubtless
your discoveries in Cuba would be of interest to
the meeting in Washington either through a talk or
an exhibit. The plans for the yellow fever meeting
have not yet been laid down and that is why I am so
indefinite at this time.

Please let me have your comments and suggestions
for consideration of our Program Committee.

closer.signed:
Wilbur A. Sawyer
Chairman, Program Committee
